story:
Ciklus radova Flash For Fantasy sam počeo 1998 godine. 2002. i 2007. su se dogodile prve dve izložbe iz tog ciklusa.

Izložba Flesh for Fantasy 3 je projekat na kome sam radio skoro sedam godina, od 2011-2017. Snimano je u nekoliko zemalja i preko deset lokacija.  Ovom izložbom želim da prkažem ženski akt kao umetničku temu, kontrast lepote i različitosti oblika ženskog tela i devastiranih ambijenata.Da bi se video kvalitet, neophodno je da izložba bude isproducirana na pravi način. To podrazumeva izradu i opremanje 50 fotografija velikih formata ,štampanje kataloga i knjige. Izložba je planirana za Mart 2018. u galeriji Progres u Beogradu i galerije Art for All u Kralja Petra u Beogradu takođe. Planirano je da isto veče budu dva otvaranja izložba a promociju monografije bi ostavili za neki drugi dan tokom izložbe. Fotografije će biti štampane na satenu i ekskluzivno opremljene. Izložbu će pratiti i video rad.

Zato sam se odlučio da zatražim od vas da budete deo mog projekta i vim putem želim da mi pomognete oko produkcije, tako što ćete donacijom dobiti moje umetničke fotografije po promo cenama . Ceo ciklus sadrži 50 fotografija potpisanih serigrafija 1-10,  ( veličine 50x75cm, 140x95cm na satenu, zategnute na blind ramove) 

Sredstva su potrebna za štampu fotografija na satenu oko 1400$, za uramljivanje oko 800$ i za katalog 600$ i za štampu pratećeg materijala 200 $, 300$ renta video opreme i ekrana

sve radove možete videti na mom sajtu http://www.ivangrlic.com/flesh-for-fantasy.html


The exhibition Flesh for Fantasy 3 is a project I have been working on for almost seven years, from 2011-2017. It has been recorded in several countries and over ten locations. With this exhibition I want to show women's nudity as an artistic theme, the contrast of beauty and the differences in the shape of a woman's body and devastated ambient. It is necessary that the exhibition be reproduced in the right way. This involves the creation and framing of 50 large format photos, printing of catalogue and book. The exhibition is planned for March 2018 at the Progres Gallery in downtown of Belgrade and the Art for All Gallery in downtown of Belgrade too.
That's why I decided to ask you to be part of my project and I want you to help me with the production, by giving me my artistic promotions at promo prices. The whole cycle contains 50 photographs of the signed seriography 1-10, (size 50x75cm, 140x95cm per satin, tightened on blind frames)

Funds are needed to print photos about $ 1400, for framing around $ 800 and for a $ 600 catalogue and  $ 500 for rent video equipment and screens.

You can see all the works on my site http://www.ivangrlic.com/flesh-for-fantasy.html

Ukratko o meni:

Nosioc statusa slobodnog umetnika od 2011., Predsednik ULUPUDS-a sekcije fotografije , Foto saveza Srbije od 2001,  Asocijacije profesionalnih fotografa od 2001.god.,  Suosnivač i predsednik udruženja “Srpska Duša-Serbian Soul Bre”,  Dobitnik specijalne nagrade 43.Majskog salona u Muzeju Primenjenih umetnosti 2011.  Osnivač, producent, menadžer i  VJ benda Serbian Jazz Bre!  Autor i izdavač knjiga Serbian Soul Bre! i Serbian Jazz Bre!  Dobitink godišnje nagdrade ULUPUDS-a za 2013.
Autor i izdavač knjiga Serbian JAZZ BRE! i Serbian Soul BRE! I zdavač više muzičkih izdanja iz oblasti Džeza i World music-a.

About me:

Freelance professional photographer and  video artist born in Belgrade, October 9th, 1977.
Education: Faculty of applied art and design, department of applied graphic 1999-2002. Graphic high school, Belgrade 1992-1995. Professional photographer since 1998. He is a member of several artistic associations: ULUPUDS section for photography, Photo association of Serbia since 2001, Association of professional photographers since 2001, Founder of studio and art workroom “Grlic” 2000. Founder and chairman of association “Srpska duša- Serbian Soul, bre.” He is the author of many photo-art series, projects and  two monograph books, such as 'Flash For Fantasy' and 'Serbian BRE!'...Since 2000 he had a huge number of solo exhibitions in galleries all around Serbia, Montenegro, Bosnia, France, Belgium, Austria...His experience as a professional photographer so far covers work in almost all domains of applied art and art photography: advertising, still life, fashion, dedicated art, portraits, theater, erotic, landscape...He was official photographer of many theater and film festivals (such as BITEF and FEST)...He had a cooperation with many marketing agencies and companies, as well as cooperation on visual identity, album covers and promo photographs for many significant musicians, bands and singers.

  Autorski ciklusi :

  Panta rei ( 2000.god. )
  Flesh for Fantasy ( 2002.god. )
  Fresh & Cruel ( 2003.god. )
  No Name ( 2003.god. )
  Serbian,BRE! ( 2001.- 2006.god. )
  Flesh for fantasy phase 2 ( 2007.god. )
  Serbian Soul, BRE! 2007.-2011.
  Serbian JAZZ, BRE! 2011.-2012.
  BGD my view  2001.-
  Music BRE!

Autorske Knjige:
Knjiga-foto-monografija Serbian Soul,BRE! 2011. u sopstvenom izdanju
Knjiga-foto-monografija Serbian JAZZ,BRE! 2012. u izdanju Službenog glasnika

IZLOŽBE ( izbor) :
2000.             “Panta Rhei” - klub “Underground”, Beograd
2001.             “Look in my eyes” - kafe “Roma”, Beograd
2002.             “Flesh for fantasy” - klub “Sova” Beograd,  Brunsweek resort, Bečići, Crna Gora
2003.             “Fresh & Cruel” - cafe “Journal”, Beograd
2003.             “No name”- Bitef art café, Beograd
2005.             Serbian, BRE!  Café gallery Štamparija, Beograd,   Club Cab, Paris, Francuska
2006.             Serbian, BRE!  Bitef teatar,  Beograd,  Club B, Brisel Belgija
2007.             Flesh for fantasy phase II- galerija Super Space, Beograd
2011.             Serbian Soul,BRE!- Ustanova Kulture Parobrod Beograd,    Kc Novi Sad,      KC Zrenjenin,    Kc Indjija, Savremena galerija Niš,  Otvoreni univerzitet Subotica,  KC Čačak,
2011.             Intro-Extra - ART MARKET Kuća Kralja Petra  Beograd
2012.             BGD. My view- Wine & Art gallery "U Podromu", Beograd
2012.             Serbian Jazz BRE!-Dom omladine Beograd,Jazzik Subotica, Savremena galerija Niš, Kc Inđija, Kc Novi Sad, Srpsko Narodno Pozorište Novi Sad,     KC Zrenjenin,     KC Valjevo,     KC Zvečan,KC Kraljevo, Galerija Kapor Drvengrad Mokra Gora
2012. Serbian Soul,BRE!- Kaiser saal klavier gallerie Beč, Austrija
2013. Serbian Jazz BRE!- Centar za Savremenu umjetnosti  Podgorica, Crna Gora
2013.             BGD my view phase II ART MARKET Kuća Kralja Petra Beograd
2014.            DOORS-Portali Kulturni centar Bol Brač Hrvatska
2014.             Serbian Jazz BRE! Herceg Novi, Crna Gora
2014.             Serbian Jazz BRE!     KDC Budimpešta Mađarska
2015.              DOORS Galerija PROGRES Beograd
2015.              BGD. My view 2015.  - Jugoexport galerija, Beograd

story:
Summary

Hello! My name is Dekel Khimker. I'm 20 years old and serving in the IDF. However, my hard work during service prevents me from following my dream of creating a professional photo album depicting one of the most sacred rituals of mankind. however, with your help i could make ends meet and finally fulfill my passion.

With your support, I can humbly make ends meet. Your financial contributions will be used to travel to exotic and photogenic locations around the country with a buddy of mine who happens to have a teeney-tiny bladder and capture the hi-jinks that ensue. It will also fund a better camera that will enable me to capture artistic urination in stunning quality.

What We Need & What You Get

At the very minimum, we're going to need 500$ to buy a relatively better camera. However, at 1500$ we'll have ourselves a real budget and we will be able to afford a higher quality camera as well as more geographic variety when it comes to photo areas. We may even be able to afford better looking clothes for whoever's peeing in the photo! The possibilities are truly endless!

We intend to release the album digitally online for free for all to witness the glory of people relieving themselves on film. However, we offer attractive incentives to anyone willing to donate to our cause! check out the perks available for your price range.

Potential Issues

As much as this project may very well change the history of art and photography, serving in the military still takes up a majority of my time. as such, i cannot offer a release date for the album. however, i intend to work on it as seriously as i possibly can! it's my life's calling, after all.

If you cant afford to donate to my cause, a share would be much appreciated! Thank you for reading.

story:
A passionate photographer who wants more then his life has to offer.I am Salik Waquas from India.I have been published in newspapers,my photo was liked by National Geographic Editor and was awarded by Cleartrip.

                                                               (some of my works)

 

Currently I took admission in BA in Cinematography.I want to capture the social issues. I use what I've learned to capture the unique qualities of places, people, and events, preferring a style that speaks to deeper emotions rather than fleeting trends in digital photography.I am willing to do a documentary based in India on Acid Attack Victims.

Acid attacks in India, like Bangladesh, have a gendered aspect to them: analyses of news reports revealed at least 72% of reported attacks included at least one female victim.However, unlike Bangladesh, India's incidence rate of chemical assault has been increasing in the past decade, with a high 27 reported cases in 2010. Altogether, from January 2002 to October 2010, 153 cases of acid assault were reported in Indian print media while 174 judicial cases were reported for the year of 2000.

The motivation behind acid attacks in India mirrors those in Bangladesh: a study of Indian news reports from January 2002 to October 2010 uncovered that victims’ rejected sex or marriage proposals motivated attacks in 35% of the 110 news stories providing a motive for the attack.

I also want my work to be published in few art galleries.Which will help spread the awareness.

Fund Raised Money Distribution

By the money raised by the campaign work on my documentary. 

Please do also see  FAQ.

story:
My intimate snapshots and portraits of people living in Latin America are a window into other everyday realities. My work explores a persons connection with other people and their role wıthin their social environment. It is a project that takes a glimpse into other cultures and other day to day realities yet through captured human expressıons and personalızed moments the vıewer ıs able to identify oneself in the humanity reflected in others.

What We Need & What You Get

The funding realized will be put towards the presentation of my work. I am shooting my photographs with Canon 550D. I aim to present my work in a compiled book and package of postcards. 

In return for your generosity I can offer:

- A shout out via social media site as a huge thank you :) If you have your own creative projects this may help to get some others to take a look at your work. 

- A postcard from the series.

-A4 Print and Postcard

-Postcard Set

-All  Postcards Sets

-A photobook

The Impact

I want to capture everyday  moments to be shared cross culturally so others can connect and identify with people who live  different realities.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't offer any money you can share my campaign on social media networks. 

Even if I do not reach the entire goal I will be grateful for everything I receive as it will still go towards my photography projects.

story:
Why am I raising money?

Greta. A five year old diagnosed early January with an incredibly rare form of Ewings Sarcoma is undergoing treatment at the BC Childrens Hospital in Vancouver, Canada.

I am a professional photographer who is documenting her journey.

My web site is www.caragrimshaw.com

Her family have dedicated their time to be with Greta, by her side every step, injection and chemo treatment. The condition is so rare that Greta is now part of multiple worldwide medical studies and there is no promise that the cancer can be fully treated or that it won't come back. It's difficult for the family and even more so for Greta who is only 5. At 5 years old visual tools are vital. The images I provide help Greta to ask the right questions, learn about what's happening to her body and to provide her family with images of memories that they can look back on. The images will be used as part of recording the medical treatments, progress and details for those in the medical industry to help treat other cases like Gretas, in the future.

The pictures also provide the families huge support network updates on Greta's progress, her treatments and a behind the scenes insight. I am honored to be trusted by the family to take such heartfelt images, it's an honour I don't take lightly.

Greta's treatment plan includes travelling from Vancouver to Boston MA late March 2015 to undergo Proton Therapy. I have been invited to join the family in Boston for a week, continuing the documenting. In order for me to travel I require funds to cover my travel costs. I am volunteering my time.

How would your donations be used?

  • Return flights from Vancouver to Boston in economy class at the end of March 2015
  • Budget hotel for 7 nights (next level up from hostel due to security of my camera gear)
  • Transportation while in Boston (public transit, airport transfers)
  • Food - Budget eating for 7 days.

How much do we need ?

$2100.00 CAD.

As a thank you for donating, you receive an exclusive first look at the daily images. See perks section for more details.

All and any additional funds received will go directly towards photoshoots (and additional shoots) with Greta and to cover indiegogo fees.

**IF YOU ARE A PROFFESIONAL COMPANY SEEKING TO HELP WITH BOOSTING THIS CAMPAIGN, PLEASE DO NOT COMMENT OR MESSAGE ME.- THANK YOU**

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone! I'm Bear of Bearphotobuffalo. I'm a cosplay photographer from Buffalo NY, and Avid D&D player and a fellow critter. This year much of my focus has been working with many amazing Critical Role cosplayers from all over. This sparked an idea to bring some of these amazing people together with the beauty of Tarot and to help out by donating all proceeds to the Critical Role Foundation.

The purpose of this project is the same as the foundation and our favorite purple Tiefling, "To leave the world better than we found it"

Updates regarding casting calls, cosplayers participating, prototype designs, and any other updates will appear here and on Twitter so make sure you're following @bearphotobflo.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are going to start with a goal of 50 full decks
  • Each pledge will be $100 USD

 

  • 20 Major Arcana Decks
  • Each pledge will be $50

 

  • You will get a gorgeous full 78 or 22 card Tarot deck complete with Gold gilt edges and a purple velvet bag.
  • All proceeds after operational costs willl be donated directly to the Critical Role Foundation.

FULL TRANSPARANCY 

  • The pledge price consists of production costs for the deck and a small allotment for travel expenses in order to work with cosplayers from all over the country and the remainder as a donation to the Critical Role Foundation.
  • all other expenses related to equipment\props\editing will be handled by myself.
  • The $100 price point ensures that you will get a beautiful, quality product and that there is a donation amount to really make a difference within the foundation.

The Impact

A little about the Critical Role Foundation:

  • "Since we began sharing stories online in 2015, one of our guiding principles has been to use our platform to create good — both in our local communities and for the world at large. Critical Role Foundation is our way of continuing this mission in a meaningful way.

    Critical Role Foundation selects and partners with outstanding non-profit organizations that carry the same values as we do and we work closely alongside each of our partners to ensure that every dollar raised is going toward programs and projects that are changing the world for the better."

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • get the word out and share our campaign on social media!
  • use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Mum's Not The Word aims to reach out to and celebrate people without children. This groundbreaking photography project shares why some women do not have children – whether it be by choice, chance, medical, unknown or circumstance.

I have been invited to exhibit during Bologna Art Week,  at Camera del Lavoro di Bologna, 23-26January.  Your support to fund the Italian show will place the childless, childfree, childless by circumstance on a  new platform in Italy, a country with a low birth-rate statistic. The artwork will debate the freedom, courage, regret and pain women without children face.

By backing the first half of my target, you will help cover the exhibition printing costs. I aim to create a triptych panel sized 240 x 120 cm. The other half the proposed target will cover travel and accommodation expenses.

Mum's not the word, was released as a photobook in June 2019, with Earthworld Publishing and since June  a touring exhibition that has  accumulated across Britain gaining notable attention through Chelsea arts Week, Blackpool  Illuminations, and Doncaster Festival of Light, This  female / female-identifying  show titled  'Reframing Identities' highlights a collective of women in photography,  hosted by Hundred Heroines initiative. The Bologna show is an extension of the Heroines Hub tour where twelve of us have been invited to exhibit.

Previoiusly seen in  The Guardian, Weekend Magazine,  the Independent.  Shortlisted Sony World Photography Awards, National Open Art Award, Julia Margaret Cameron Award. Shown  in Cologne, Barcelona, Athens Photobook Festival,  British and French TV.

If you can't donate financially, please make some noise about this campaign. Childlessness affects 20-25% of the population. Share this with your childless friends by using the  Indiegogo share tools,  or if its sensitive (and it is for many) send them a private message.

story:
Who am I?

My name is David C. Hill and I've been a keen photographer since around the age of two, when I captured hundreds of incredible images on my 1976 Fisher Price Pocket Camera. Unfortunately, my parents then had to invest in a pair of clown trousers so the thing could fit in my pocket. 

It was around this time that my colouring and retouching skills reached a new level of expertise. Of course, in those days "photo retouching" involved drawing a moustache on Felicity Kendal's face with a big fat marker pen - but it must have been evident that I had God-given creative talents. 

Some of the work I produced on that camera was Pulitzer Prize winning material. The crème de la crème of photo journalism. 

Sadly, disaster struck in 1979 when my family acquired our first dog - a German Shepherd by the name of Max - who ate all my Fisher Price masterpieces. I know, what were the chances?

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 



Max really laid the foundations for my love of dogs, and was the proverbial cherry on top of my already happy childhood. In 1988, shortly after Max passed away, we adopted Ben [the Labrador X] whose arrival coincided with my first real camera. 

Ben later became the primary focus of all my photographs, as I'd drop my film into Boots and wait a dog's age for the pictures to be developed. And some of them came out pretty good...

Ben passed away in 2004, and it would be another ten years before my next dog appeared on the scene. A dog that would change my life more than any of her predecessors. 

In the time I've had Luna I've faced many battles... and while the untrained eye sees her as the catalyst, the truth is that she's saved my life more than any human ever could. 

As Tennessee Williams said, "Life is all memory" and although it often seems to drag like Brexit negotiations, it really does pass in the blink of an eye. 

This campaign, if successful, will give me the tools I need to forge my photography career, and produce images almost as good as those I captured on my Fisher Price Pocket Camera all those years ago.

What I Need

In total I need £3,000 of funding - so let's "break it down" (as MC Hammer once said) and be completely transparent and honest about where this money is going.

The DSLR camera. Pretty essential for any professional photographer.

The lenses. Having two or three quality lenses will allow me to adapt to any environment. 

Lighting equipment and studio backdrops. Lighting will be required for all the studio shoots, while a green screen background will assist me in post-production.

iPad Pro and Apple Pencil. I concluded that this would be far more cost effective than a Wacom graphics tablet, and a device that can be used for photo retouching and drawing. 

What You Get

The perks range from digital images to a professional photo shoot, photo books, videos and animations of your pet. And if you don't have a pet yourself then you can gift your perk to a friend or family member.

We all love our pets, and most of them are only around for 15% of our lifetime - and the smaller pets might only bless us with their presence for two or three years. So I'd like to capture them in a series of high quality photos or videos that can be cherished for the rest of your life - and even shared with future generations.

In 2016 I funded my book Lunakita: A Dog Log via crowd funding, and, although it took a couple of years, it was finally published in December 2018.

The difference here is that it's not going to take me two years to launch the business. If successfully funded in May 2019 then all I need to do is purchase the equipment and I'll be good to go. In fact I already have clients lined up, so I can hit the ground running

Risks & Challenges

Pet photography isn't about sticking a camera in a dog's face and taking hundreds of photos in the hope that one or two turn out okay. There'll be days when I'll need to lie on my belly in a wet field until I capture the perfect shot... before driving home, caked in mud and fox poop. 

In my 44-year lifetime I've never met a dog that doesn't like me, but I'm sure that will change - so I need to be prepared for any situation. I've spent five years with an exceptionally skittish and demanding dog and although I know a lot about animal behaviour it would make sense for me to enrol on an animal behaviour course. 

I'd also like to learn the basics of animal first aid, so if I do come across a pet choking or having a seizure at least I'll know what to do.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute then I'd be delighted if you could please share this page with your family and friends to help spread the campaign far and wide. 

Thank you in advance.

So I'd like to capture them in a series of high quality photos or videos that can be cherished for the rest of your life - and even shared with future generations.

In 2016 I funded my book Lunakita: A Dog Log via crowd funding, and, although it took a couple of years, it was finally published in December 2018.
The difference here is that it's not going to take me two years to launch the business. If successfully funded in May 2019 then all I need to do is purchase the equipment and I'll be good to go. In fact I already have clients lined up, so I can hit the ground running

Risks & Challenges
Pet photography isn't about sticking a camera in a dog's face and taking hundreds of photos in the hope that one or two turn out okay. There'll be days when I'll need to lie on my belly in a wet field until I capture the perfect shot... before driving home, caked in mud and fox poop. 
In my 44-year lifetime I've never met a dog that doesn't like me, but I'm sure that will change - so I need to be prepared for any situation. I've spent five years with an exceptionally skittish and demanding dog and although I know a lot about animal behaviour it would make sense for me to enrol on an animal behaviour course. 
I'd also like to learn the basics of animal first aid, so if I do come across a pet choking or having a seizure at least I'll know what to do.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't afford to contribute then I'd be delighted if you could please share this page with your family and friends to help spread the campaign far and wide. Thank you in advance.

story:
What is it?

Hi. My Name is Narges. I'm an Iranian photographer based in San Francisco. I have documented many different people stories in the past. Right now I want to invite you to join me with my latest project.

I grew up in a northern coastal area of Iran where ordinary people struggle to make a living by fishing. Right now their lifeline is under threat from an ongoing environmental crisis. 

I hope you can be part of this cause and help this group of innocent people who are very close to my heart. 

What We Need & What You Get

I'm almost done but I need your help to complete this journey. I'll use the money I raise for the final leg of the traveling and finalizing the project to make a photo book and exhibition. I'm going to rough it out and travel in the most efficient ways to make sure every cent goes a long way to get this story out. 

In return, you can sign-up for a full color printed book, and invitation to the final exhibition (in San Francisco) and a behind the scenes movie to learn what it was like as well as regular social media updates of the progress when possible.

Why should you care?

It's very important for me to give these people a voice and let the world hear about this injustice. That's is why I started a photo documentary project out of my own expense and spent about 10 years learning about their stories and capturing thousands of images. 

Risks & Challenges

I have a lot of experience in doing things like this (I left home to pursue a life of a wondering nomad when I was just a teenager) but anything can happen.  While I'd  do everything I can to get this done, the result could be something that I haven't anticipated.  But that's what makes this worth trying.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't signup for any of the perks you can help me by spreading the word with your friends who are passionate about helping people from remote areas that never get any attention from the rest of the world.

story:
I like to take pictures...

I've spent almost my entire life in the military or working overseas and my goal is to now find a way to stay home.  Photobucket List (@photobucketlist on Instagram) began as a way to simply blog about my transition to becoming a photographer and it's quickly become so much more.  It's now a new profession and a means to move away from having to make money by spending time abroad:

  • This campaign helps me both get my photography out in the open as well as fund my first art showing
  • By purchasing a print you're helping me take a huge step in the direction of becoming a photographer 
  • Becoming a photographer is extremely hard these days since everyone with a camera phone and some filters can capture things that photographers 10 years ago only dreamed of.  By purchasing a print you're helping support the professional photography industry and keep alive a professional that only a few can be successful in. 

Each photo is taken by me! 

My goal with photobucketlist.com is to blog about my transition of becoming a photographer.  As I learn about the different aspects of photography I blog about what I learn, what works and what doesn't.  My hope is that by recording my transition I can also help others who follow after me. 

The Impact:

  • What do you change by purchasing a print?  Actually a lot.  Right now I don't make a full-time living from photography, but this is a big start.  My hope is that eventually I can make this a full on profession.  The problem is I can't do it alone.  A photographer without a customer is just an enthusiast, but with your help I can make it a career. 

Risks & Challenges

It's taken a lot for me to reach out of my comfort zone of work and daily life and venture into a world of photography.  The road has been slow with plenty of setbacks but no matter what I do I always find myself going back to picking up a camera.  My biggest challenge of all has been finding a way to stand out in a sea of other photographers.  With little blips of success here and there I am finally able to see this as an actual career... with your help of course. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't want to buy no worries! You can also help by:

  • Following me on @photobucketlist on Instagram
  • Reading/visiting my website photobucketlist.com
  • Telling others about my work!

story:
My name is Kristi and I am a third year photography student at the University of West London. I've been into photography all of my life but really got interested in pursuing it as a career in college. Over the years I've discovered my true passion of architecture and social documentary photography. Now it's time for me to get my work out there and show off my passion. 

 

What the Campaign is About:

This campaign is all about getting myself to my degree show. It's a great opportunity providing great networking and possibilities to win some great awards. Getting to the Old Truman Brewery is important to me as it's my final chance to really show off my work before entering into the big wide world after university. 

Anyone who chooses to contribute to this campaign will help me achieve a number of things. It will truly help me get my work out in to the world giving me some much needed exposure. You will also contribute to the printing of my work helping me get it to the best possible quality. 

What I Need:

I need roughly £500 to get me going. Just under £400 is needed as my share of the hire for the exhibition space and the other £100 will go towards the printing and framing of my work. 

Even if I don't reach my entire goal the money will still go towards the exhibition space and printing the more raised the better it will be.

This isn't going to be an easy amount to raise but it's for such a great opportunity I will do as much as possible to gain the funds I need. I plan to fundraise through this campaign and other events I plan to set up. Keep posted and attend any fundraising events you can.

Even if you can't donate any money, just sharing this campaign would be a great help to get it out to as many people as possible. Also coming to the exhibition taking place at the end of June to see my work would be greatly appreciated.

I hope you can all help and keep yourselves posted as this campaign expands.

story:
We live in a world where makeup, waist trainers, and plastic surgery are deemed necessary to make a girl/woman feel confident, strong, and gorgeous. As a working model, Breona sees this first-hand and knows it's not a healthy way to portray fashion or the personal lives of others.  She wants to promote, through photos and fashion, that differences from the norm should be celebrated, not hidden. 

Throughout her fashion career, Breona has been treated poorly for this very reason. Many agencies refuse to represent her because of her height. Others look down on her scarred skin. But this doesn't stop Breona. She remains determined to show the world that women should feel stunning just the way they are-- that no makeup or plastic surgery will ever truly replace the value of their #NaturalBodyBeauty.

Come join us in helping everyone-- moms, students, models, children-- realize their true #NaturalBodyBeauty, no matter what others might say.

video credit: https://www.tabithaandelin.com/

www.breonawilson.com

story:
From AnalogueVibes we want to present you our project through three brief points:  

 

  • AnalogueVibes Magazine was born December 2014 as a digital magazine at the hands of Miguel Rózpide Pazó, a young and passionate advocate of analogue photography as a means of expression and communication. The project starts with three well-defined intentions: the first one is to publicize and, thus, make known all those photographers who use analog material in his works, the second one is to display and disseminate new content through interviews, biographies of photographers, news and articles and, the third one is to offer to the public the delight of a high-quality kind of photography that is not on the mainstream.  
  • September: September promises new hope for Analogue Vibes and its more than 21,600 followers on social networks like Instagram as the doors open to a new and well-updated paper version that is counting on the collaboration of amazing and well-known photographers such as Atisha Paulson, among others. Besides, the magazine will continue submitting features and interviews accompanying all the dazzling snapshots that will be set within its pages.
  • The power to fulfill a dream. We have the idea. We have the format. We have the channel. We have the means. We have the material. We have determination. We have perseverance. We have illusion. We have a dream. The only thing that keep us in touch with it, is your help. From the direction and editing of AnalogueVibes we ask for your cooperation, not to build a prosperous future, it will not be necessary, we seek the prosperity of the present moment, we seek your sponsorship, we seek the support of future help in order to make our intentions and efforts worthwhile, ensuring that AnalogueVibes reaches as many people as possible via social media (Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, Website and the new printed format on paper), so we can be an important benchmark in the market and in the photography world.

Thank you so much, 

AnalogueVibes

Links:

www.analoguevibes.com 

www.instagram.com/analoguevibes

story:
"The indigenous peoples of Brazil face a serious threat to their own survival with the emergence of the COVID-19 pandemic. Five centuries ago, these ethnic groups were decimated by diseases brought by European colonizers. Today with this new scourge spreading rapidly throughout Brazil, native communities, some living in isolation in the Amazon Basin, may disappear completely since they have no means of combating COVID-19."

The petition raised by world-renowned photographer Sebastiao Salgado (signed by celebrities like Madonna, Meryl Streep, Brad Pitt) is a wake-up call to keep our attention high on the extremely difficult situation in the entire Amazon region.

Because of the pandemic, Amazonian indigenous people are even more threatened by the unscrupulous interests of governments and private companies and illegal traders, that are bringing the epidemic into their territories. Moreover, the coronavirus has become the pretext to further silence their voice, reduce their rights and bring them to their knees leaving them without means of sustenance and adequate health care.

This is why I feel the urgency to give as much voice as possible to Human Forest project, and I am asking for your support to be louder and louder!

 

The Human Forest project

 

The Amazon is the green lung of the Earth for everyone. Few consider the fact that it is a place inextricably connected with human beings who have lived there for centuries, direct witnesses of its uniqueness and of the ongoing social and environmental upheavals.

At the end of 2017 I embarked on a journey alone with the intention of crossing the Amazon region for two months, from Ecuador to Brazil. In the remote Zòna Intangible of the Yasuní National Park, created in 1999 to protect the Waorani territory and other indigenous groups - including the Tagaeri and the Taromenani who have chosen to live in voluntary isolation - I met with the Waorani community of Bameno in the heart of the Amazon rainforest of Ecuador, one of the Latin American countries most affected by the Coronavirus

First presented to the world in 1956 as "the worst people on Earth" by LIFE Magazine, after the tragic contact attempt covered by the reporter Cornell Capa, then invasively civilized between the sixties and seventies, the Waorani underwent in the arc of only two generations a very strong social and cultural metamorphosis. Today, the Waorani survive suspended between an ancestral lifestyle of communion with the forest, now compromised, and a predatory modernity, in an indifferent world.

Human Forest centers on people, in the attempt of overcoming stereotypes about indigenous peoples and focusing on the inseparable relationship between human beings and the forest in the Amazonian culture. An invitation to reflect on the profound meaning of the sense of limit and the human condition.

Waorani means "Humans". It is from here that I believe we should all start again.

 

Why your support is important

 

My project aims to raise questions and awareness about the history, present and future of the Amazon rainforest and the people who live there, especially now that they are even more threatened by the pandemic of Coronavirus.

I have been invited to exhibit Human Forest at Milan Photofestival 2020 and this is a great opportunity for the project, an important stage an important step to give it maximum visibility.

The project is curated by Paola Riccardi and the exhibition will be hosted from the 15th to the 31st of October 2020 at Galleria Alcentoquarantadue in Viale Monza 142, Milano.

Organizing a successful solo exhibition for the Milan Photofestival 2020 thou requires a lot of resources, such as printing and framing the 32 photographs, paying the festival fee, renting the gallery space, paying the curator fee, promoting the event and organizing the vernissage.

I am hoping to raise €4.200 to cover all the Milan Photofestival 2020 exhibition expenses and the campaign fees (5% Indiegogo fee+ PayPal fees+ bank transaction fees).

The money won't cover any of the costs for traveling to the Amazon region and making Human Forest come true (which I paid by myself), and I'm not trying to get any profit out of it either.

In exchange for your support, you'll be able to choose between some amazing rewards: they're all listed on the right, so pick your favorite! 

I also hope to be able to move my exhibition out of Italy, increasing awareness about the indigenous people that live in the Amazon Rainforest and the injustices they are subject to, using my photographs to ignite the discussion. So, any extra funds raised beyond the campaign goal will help me carrying out the next steps in order to bring my exhibition to audiences around the world.

 

If you care, share!

 

The main ingredient of any crowdfunding is people! So, please, help me sharing the campaign with your friends and families on social media (using the buttons on the top of the page). Let people know about the Human Forest project!

Even if you're unable to contribute financially today, you can still make a huge difference spreading the word about this campaign.

Thank you in advance from the bottom of my heart! I am incredibly grateful to you for believing in my project and supporting my exhibition. I hope to meet you in Milan!

(opening event on October 15th 2020 – I will update all the details soon)

 

Who am I?

Ciao! My name is Marina Tana and I was born in Pavia (Italy) in 1979. I like to describe myself as a renaissance person, or this is at least how I try to justify my many passions. I am an engineer, a manager, a Philosophy scholar, but above all I am a passionate traveler, photographer and storyteller.

I unexpectedly began to travel alone in 2014, approaching photography as a further space for reflection and personal research, an enhanced gaze capable of creating an intimate contact between the solo traveler and the surrounding natural and human environment.

My travels spring from the desire to observe how humans and territory have influenced each other over time, developing a multiplicity of cultural, spiritual and environmental interrelationships.

I am particularly interested in cultural and visual stereotypes, and in the decolonization of Arts.

story:
"Chaps, I'm kicking around an idea for a Leek Blues Festival sometime in October"

This message appeared on my facebook page early in 2013, I knew very little about Blues music and had only photographed half a dozen gigs, and was now being asked to help arrange Leek's first Blues Festival, along with a group of artists and music fans. 

Now nearly 5 years later I'm sitting here looking at the latest lineup for the 5th festival with around 20 venues and 50+ bands

I'm also now a big fan of Blues music, in awe of all the performers I've seen over the past few years, extremely proud to have been a small part of the group that organizes the event and even prouder of my home town for supporting the whole thing in such a big way.

The Plan

Using the pictures taken over the last 4 years, we aim to mount a free exhibition during the festival, using at least 2 of the venues, if not more, to display the pictures. The higher the sum of money raised the more pictures can go into the venues.

What you get

There are a number perks but the main one is that you get one of the pictures from the exhibition, you get to choose the picture, it is then printed on canvas and displayed during the festival. Once the exhibition is finished your picture will be sent to you.

story:
Thank you for taking your time to visit the Indiegogo page of my project. I appreciate your interest. If you haven’t yet, please see the gallery above to view a collection of my artworks. 


About me 

I’m an emerging visual artist based in Amsterdam, currently studying at Gerrit Rietveld Academie. My work in mix-media, with a strong interest in photography, expresses the relationship between man and (natural) environment, the Universe and the laws governing order. I’m interested in the human psyche and our existence on the globe, which strongly reflects onto my art.  When conducting research, I focus on the activities of humankind and their indivisible bonds with the ambience. This explores how the achievements of civilization are bound up with the consequences of pursuing progress. Nature is my inspiration and reference point. In my life, I look for a balance between its soothingness and vibrant urbanism, so do I in art.  

 

About the project

Two of my projects: solo expo and single photo, were selected for Rotterdam Photo Festival 2020, which takes place during The Art Rotterdam Week. One of the images is shown during
World Press Photo Rotterdam. As a young artist, this is a huge opportunity for international exposure and growing my network. I want to take advantage of these chances, thrive and push my career further. 
It appears challenging, considering the scale and gravity of the events, yet my previous artistic
experience ensures me to feel confident.


Outside in 
An attempt to interpret the relationship between man as both an individual and a part of society. The spectacle of a single man trapped in the realms of the contemporary world and the expression of continuous existential pain in an anaesthetized surrounding. A series of photographs as a negative criticism of the rapid economic progress, consumerism, capitalism and indifference to the detriment of the individual.


Mind Traverses
A reflection on the current transition in the way of living, thinking and a positive assessment on the direction of the development that considers not only modernity but also nature and its sources. A joint venture of both appears to be a quintessential solution helping to resolve issues faced currently by humankind; without causing harm for milieu. 


Support me 

To execute my ideas I need your (financial) help. All the funds collected here will be spent on
production and promotion costs. A section of the funds will be paid to the organization, to help run and create these beautiful events. By donating to my project you support not only me but the whole photography community consisting of amateurs, professionals, artists, promoters and everyone who loves lens arts ☺

“As a small independent organization that consists of passionate photography freelancers, we want to create a platform that caters to a wide spectrum of photographers. However, we cannot make it work without your financial contribution as we are only partially funded. With your contribution, we cover organizational, productional and promotional costs to make sure your work is facilitated and promoted in the best way possible" 

-Rotterdam Photo Festival

Every backer can choose a perk: a digital hug or physical postcard/poster with the photo selected for the shows (first in the gallery up above). Every cent counts. Though if you cannot support financially, you can still help me out; by sharing this page on your social media, following my profile or visiting the exhibitions. The opening takes place on the 6th of February. Everyone is welcome!


More info: 

  • Rotterdam Photo Festival 06-09/02_2020
    https://www.rotterdamphotofestival.com/visit
  • World Press Photo Rotterdam 18/01-08/02_2020 
    https://www.worldpressphotoexporotterdam.com/en...

 

Stay in touch and see more: https://www.ananaz.eu

I do offer prints of my other photographs. Please feel free to contact me if you're interested in
getting some.


With love,
David

story:
Hi everyone!For the last year I’ve been trying answer the question: What is the future of film photography? Can new cameras be manufactured? Will we have enough spares to keep the old ones going? What developing options will we have in 2030?

I’m definitely not the only one constantly asking things. However, I have the fortunate possibility to explore these themes almost full time and had the chance to hear people from over 100 countries voice their opinion. Their questions led me to the idea of answering them by creating a conference.

 

The dawn of film is arriving, judging by the results of the Save Analog Cameras campaign we launched in April this year. With more than 4500 entries, the future seems quite bright - as over 55% of respondents interested in saving analog photography are under the age of 34. The community is rallying together to save film photography, as it has been for several years under various hashtags and through vocal blogs, but now stronger and younger than ever. However, to get answers to many questions, we need to have a conversation with the analog industry

To do this I propose a conference that unites the voices of the analog community and industry, a day packed full of answers to the community's biggest questions through interesting presentations, interviews and panel discussions. We plan to host the conference as a hybrid of a small actual physical event that aims at a BIG online presence that the community can enjoy via livestreams and afterwards freely on YouTube – very much like the popular TED talks concept.

 

What will the conference contain?

The presentations, interviews and panel discussions will be packed into one super Sunday on 26.11.2017 . We’re working with our partners to bring the most influential people in the analog photography scene together and get them to share their point of view on the future of film. Most importantly, we want the content to reflect the backers’ and community’s wishes.

The backers traveling all the way to Finland can enjoy a day of photography workshops on Saturday, with a lot of social gatherings and networking opportunities in the evening. On Monday 27th of November we’ll have a post-conference gathering to process possible action points in smaller teams.

The amount of content and panelists is directly linked to the budget we get from this campaign and to the feedback we get from backers, so it will change during the coming months. With the 10 000€ budget we are looking at having 5 main themes discussed and recorded:

Discussions

1. The future of Large Format and Darkroom work and questions arising from it.

Contributors: Nicolas Llasera / Nicos Photography Show, Lomig Perrotin / Film Washi additional participants to be confirmed.

Topic: The user base of Large Format photography has been growing steadily and with the introduction of cheaper entry models and hand made beautiful new/resurrected manufacturers, it is getting a lot of attention worldwide. Darkrooms are also seeing a revival of users. What challenges are people constantly seeing and how to address it?  

Objectives: Create a guide with tips/tricks from users and service providers around the world.

2. The future of cameras: Is there a way to get new cameras into the market?

Contributors: Bellamy Hunt / Japan Camera Hunter , Raffaello Pallandri / Open Camera Project, additional participants to be confirmed.

Topic: Some parts of the global demand for cameras can be well met with the existing stock, but for instance the compact camera market is in dire need of new cameras. How could these cameras be made? What modern technologies could be used, that where not available 15 years ago? Could a Open source ideology be used?

Objective: Create a framework/forum for engineers and designers to collaborate with each other, bounce ideas and make known what knowhow is already available around the world.

 

3. The future of cameras: How do we keep the global camera stock functional for the next generation?

Host: Hamish Gill / (35mmc.com)

Topic: A conversation with engineers and repair specialists on the condition of the used camera stock in the world, the biggest challenges and possible solutions that can be done to keep the stock usable.

Objective: Create a foundation for a global directory/resource for repair specialists. Combine the results of the conversation, community involvement, 35mmc.com repair directory and the #saveanalogcameras repair resource mapping results.

 

4. The future of scanning

Contributors: Maximilien Steinberg (NationPhoto.com) and Abe Fettig (FilmLab-app), additional participants to be confirmed.

Topic: Scanning is an essential part of the analog workflow, especially for the digital era newcomers entering the market. Most professional scanning equipment was designed in the era of Windows XP and are nearing the end of their usage time. What solutions will there be available for the home scanning scene and professional services in 2020?

Objective: Showcase the different options available now, the problem we are facing with sustainability and inspire community members working in maybe a slightly different field (for example phone camera development or medical instruments creation) to take part in the conversation with their knowhow.

 

5. The future of developing

Contributors: Maximilien Steinberg (NationPhoto.com), LAB-BOX / Ars-Imago

Topic: The days of one lab developing several million rolls of film a year are definitely behind us. As manufacturing industrial developing machines will not be commercially viable in the future, we will have to cope with the machines we have. It seems we are moving towards a future where there will be 5-20 bigger centralized industrial labs per contintent and a huge crowd of people doing home development. However a midrange option will probably emerge, with small boutique developers poping up around mid-sized cities, doing all developments by hand, having a gallery/cafe/courses creating their own customer base.

Objective: Creating guidelines/tutorials for each of these three (large scale, boutique, home development) development aspects to grow sustainably and letting the community know their options. 

 

 

Confirmed keynotes:

(more will be added as confirmations/budget clear up)

A look at the global situation /Juho Leppänen Cameraventures.com

The deep insights into the #saveanalogcameras campaign and what it tells us. Unless the survey blows up 10-20x from the 4500 answers so far we will have time to go through the open form answers by November. This will give us an idea of what is the situation of repair shops, developing options and film availability specially for the parts of the community that do not live in big metropolitan areas with acceptable local services.

How we turned back to shoot weddings fully on film? / Sarah  & Ben Collier  thefilmphotographersworkshop.com / takenbysarah.com

"In 2015 we struggled to shoot as "hybrid" photographers at our weddings (portraits had long been all film), too scared to let go of our digital crutch, yet finding that it made the day extremely stressful and we were producing mediocre work at times because of it. We knew we needed to choose one or the other to produce the best work that we could for our clients, and we felt strongly that film was what fulfilled our vision in the best way. We've realized that, in many ways, film is much easier to shoot in different lighting situations than digital, and we've fully embraced it as our medium of choice."

 

Why 10 000€?

We have a free venue sponsored by the local camera industry and we have some volunteers for the event. The goverment of Finland and City of Tampere are doing their share to support and Cameraventures is dedicating personel to this. But there are still costs in hosting a dozen or so speakers/artists for the weekend and in a good quality video/PA/lighting crew for a day, that are not covered in the budget. If 10 000€ is reached, we can deliver what is promised now in this IGG campaign.  

 

Where will the conference be held?

For 99% of those reading this, the conference will be enjoyed from the warmth of their own couch. The brave and adventurous among us will meet in Tampere, Finland, in the 26th of November 2017, because we are masochists (the weather + amount of light combo has a strong chance to be unpleasant).

BUT we figured that if the biggest Tech Conference in Europe can be held in Finland in the same week with 17 500 attendees, so can this. Finland has always been a bridge connecting the east to the west — the perfect location for a conference with a global perspective.

 

The team building the conference

The team in Finland consists of me (Juho Leppänen) and our coder Misa when we are available from our daily routines at Cameraventures, as the other guys in the team will take some of our workload. Cameraventures.com is a startup that got known for its efforts saving analog cameras through an online platform dedicated for reclaimed camera gear. Lately it has ventured into becoming a digital bridge between the community and the industry through maps (top film labs, repair centers, social media influencers, etc.) that #saveanalogcameras project will publish once they are processed.

Since the aim of the Future of Film conference is bigger and more global than what two guys in Finland can handle, we’re being helped by these wonderful people:

Vincent Moschetti - a Frenchman living in Ireland and running the OneYearWithFilmOnly.com blog.

Sam Sanchez - a Filipino living in Germany keeping you guys informed about what is happening during the formation of the conference.


 

Why?

During the #saveanalogcameras process I’ve witnessed just how diverse the worldwide analog photography scene is. I also came to understand that the core reasons why people are shooting film are shared by the community all around the world. We want to enjoy life and preserve tangible memories through the centuries without the worry of them becoming unreadable data. We’ve gone through 20 years of ‘darkness’ and seen the huge global support network slowly deteriorate, yet the spirit of collaboration and mentorship is stronger than ever. I can’t be the only one to see the immense beauty in what we have as a community.

The Night of Film, as I call the last 20 years in the history of photochemical imaging, consisted of devastating changes to both the industry and the community that supported it. Kodak and Fujifilm were the size of Coca-Cola and Pepsi in 1997 – and the rivalry between them was just as fierce. In addition, battles between camera manufacturers and high profit margins in developing shops painted the landscape as brutally competitive and restricted. You do not have to be very old to remember how conversations between the photography community and industry were almost hostile. An entire generation has had to pass until the scene transformed into the collaborative culture now emerging around the globe.

My dream is that we can hold on to the culture of mentoring and getting together even as the community of film photographers now has started to expand. To extend the best parts of this new culture to newcomers is one main reason why we need to talk about how we see the future of film. #futureoffilm

 

It is all up to you

My primary goal is to stir up conversation around the future of film (#futureoffilm). I firmly believe that talking about film in a positive way, one where the future of analog is bright, will bring more enthusiasts to the scene. I am sure that if you had the grit to read this far, you will keep fighting for film even if this conference wouldn't become a reality and so will I.  However if you feel that you would want to hear the newest information of the analog  photography scene in a TED talks manner, please back us up!

Thanks a lot for your support and a special thanks to all of those who fought the long fight during the Night, turning this community into the precious thing it is now.

- Juho Leppänen

For a copy of the press release and/or information on who to contact with which enquiry, please see our campaign site at future-of-film.com

Ps. Just to illustrate how small the world has gotten and how global the generation building up the new analog culture is, I'll share the story behind the beautiful scene on the graphics of this campaign. I was searching online for a picture that would encapsulate the hopes of the new dawn, and have an analog element to it when Google turned up with the blog of Nicholas, a Large Format landscape photographer from the UK. I fell in love with this BTS shot and sent a message to Nicholas through Twitter. He replied in 15 minutes from the back of a camper van in New Zealand, where it was almost midnight. Nicholas graciously let us use the picture and went to sleep while we kept creating the campaign with the team in Finland, Ireland and Germany.

story:
The Exhibition

This exhibition will be a display of striking photographic portraits from the 1970s by Baba Alabi of Ibadan, western Nigeria. Its inspiration is the elaborate head-gear (gele) worn by Yoruba women and the expensive hand-woven fabric (aso-oke), indigenous to the Yoruba people and worn by them mainly on special family occasions. This theme, marrying culture with fashion, which Baba Alabi has captured in his photography over the decades, is just one of the many themes that celebrate and distinguish the Yoruba people. Planned for the UK’s 2016 Black History Month of October, the exhibition, aims to present the joys of diversity and to promote the appreciation of distinct cultures. It will open with a private view and drinks reception for its funders. The photographs in the exhibition will be individually hand-printed, by one of London’s few remaining traditional photo labs, to a high quality using the pre-digital darkroom process. 

In addition to having the satisfaction of making this exhibition possible, our backers would get to own a piece of Yoruba photography history and culture. Pick one of out top two perks and you will either bag a numbered limited edition print of Olu Alabi's images or one of the actual photographs in the exhibition.

 

Olu Alabi

Baba Alabi, is a veteran photographer who lives and plied his trade in Ibadan. Baba Alabi’s was one of the main commercial studios, during the 1970s to 1990s, photographing Ibadan folk at their weddings, christenings, graduations, funerals and other family celebrations. He is now one of the few Nigerian photographers who have managed to preserve part of his collection of commercial work from his active years in the 1970s. It is thanks to his foresight that we have this opportunity to get a glimpse of a golden period of Yoruba photography, before the arrival of digital photos.

 

Why have this exhibition?

As the curator I, Depo Olukotun, was inspired by the idea of using photographs of the Yoruba people, whose presence is just as strong in the UK as it is in Nigeria or Northern Brazil, as an example of the fact that Black Britain is made up of a range of interesting cultures. My objective is to educate people about themselves and individual groups about each other.  The Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition also aims to highlight the fact that there are many different photographic heritages, out there in the world, which need to be preserved for their value as information about unique histories and cultures.

 

St Mary-at-Hill: Come and celebrate with us in this historic venue

The Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition will be held in the accessible and salubrious setting of the Church of St Mary-at-Hill. Right at the centre of the City of London by the Monument, Sir John Betjeman described it as “the least spoilt and the most gorgeous interior” in the City. This venue is also historic, having been rebuilt to a design by the renowned Sir Christopher Wren after the 1666 Great Fire of London. It has been at the heart of 2016’s 350th anniversary commemorations of the Fire.

Choose one of the three top perks offered in this Indiegogo campaign and join us at the drinks reception to celebrate the opening of the Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition at this historic venue.

 

What will your contributions be supporting?

Your contributions will:

  • Help fund the cost of the exhibition, including the hand-printed photographs that will be exhibited.
  • Fund a donation to the educational charity of St Peter’s Aremo Church Ibadan, where Baba Alabi was one of the resident photographers
  • Support future educational and cultural events
  • Fund further photographic heritage research and preservation projects and in effect support the foresight and efforts of photographers like Baba Alabi.
  • Help pay Baba Alabi’s copyright fees.

 

The Curator and Organiser

Depo Olukotun is a researcher whose area of interest is West African photographic history, specifically Yoruba photographic history and traditions. He has a Masters degree in the History of Art and Photography from Birkbeck College, University of London. As a curator, he runs GalleriaClic, an online art gallery with years of experience of running pop-up galleries and organising exhibitions.

 

Risks and Challenges

This is an all-or-nothing fundraising campaign. If we do not raise the whole £4500, the exhibition cannot be mounted. If we do not reach our target each backer will be given a full refund of the pledges.

Please visit and keep an eye on www.galleriaclic.co.uk/gele for updates on the exhibition and information on Yoruba Photography
story_txt:
The ExhibitionThis exhibition will be a display of striking photographic portraits from the 1970s by Baba Alabi of Ibadan, western Nigeria. Its inspiration is the elaborate head-gear (gele) worn by Yoruba women and the expensive hand-woven fabric (aso-oke), indigenous to the Yoruba people and worn by them mainly on special family occasions. This theme, marrying culture with fashion, which Baba Alabi has captured in his photography over the decades, is just one of the many themes that celebrate and distinguish the Yoruba people. Planned for the UK’s 2016 Black History Month of October, the exhibition, aims to present the joys of diversity and to promote the appreciation of distinct cultures. It will open with a private view and drinks reception for its funders. The photographs in the exhibition will be individually hand-printed, by one of London’s few remaining traditional photo labs, to a high quality using the pre-digital darkroom process. In addition to having the satisfaction of making this exhibition possible, our backers would get to own a piece of Yoruba photography history and culture. Pick one of out top two perks and you will either bag a numbered limited edition print of Olu Alabi's images or one of the actual photographs in the exhibition. Olu AlabiBaba Alabi, is a veteran photographer who lives and plied his trade in Ibadan. Baba Alabi’s was one of the main commercial studios, during the 1970s to 1990s, photographing Ibadan folk at their weddings, christenings, graduations, funerals and other family celebrations. He is now one of the few Nigerian photographers who have managed to preserve part of his collection of commercial work from his active years in the 1970s. It is thanks to his foresight that we have this opportunity to get a glimpse of a golden period of Yoruba photography, before the arrival of digital photos. Why have this exhibition?As the curator I, Depo Olukotun, was inspired by the idea of using photographs of the Yoruba people, whose presence is just as strong in the UK as it is in Nigeria or Northern Brazil, as an example of the fact that Black Britain is made up of a range of interesting cultures. My objective is to educate people about themselves and individual groups about each other.  The Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition also aims to highlight the fact that there are many different photographic heritages, out there in the world, which need to be preserved for their value as information about unique histories and cultures. St Mary-at-Hill: Come and celebrate with us in this historic venueThe Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition will be held in the accessible and salubrious setting of the Church of St Mary-at-Hill. Right at the centre of the City of London by the Monument, Sir John Betjeman described it as “the least spoilt and the most gorgeous interior” in the City. This venue is also historic, having been rebuilt to a design by the renowned Sir Christopher Wren after the 1666 Great Fire of London. It has been at the heart of 2016’s 350th anniversary commemorations of the Fire.Choose one of the three top perks offered in this Indiegogo campaign and join us at the drinks reception to celebrate the opening of the Gele ati Asọ́-Oke exhibition at this historic venue. What will your contributions be supporting?Your contributions will:
Help fund the cost of the exhibition, including the hand-printed photographs that will be exhibited.

Support future educational and cultural events

Help pay Baba Alabi’s copyright fees.

He has a Masters degree in the History of Art and Photography from Birkbeck College, University of London. As a curator, he runs GalleriaClic, an online art gallery with years of experience of running pop-up galleries and organising exhibitions. Risks and ChallengesThis is an all-or-nothing fundraising campaign. If we do not raise the whole £4500, the exhibition cannot be mounted. If we do not reach our target each backer will be given a full refund of the pledges.Please visit and keep an eye on www.galleriaclic.co.uk/gele for updates on the exhibition and information on Yoruba Photography

story:
BeWoman – Zeit Frau zu sein, Zeit Du selbst zu sein. 
Wir wollen dir zeigen, wie schön Du bist. Du bist nicht zufrieden mit deinem Körper – fühlst Dich nicht schön genug? 

Das ist Nonsens – DU bist wunderschön und wir zeigen es dir, ohne Dich zu verändern! 


Mit BeWoman wollen wir jeder Frau zeigen, dass sie schön ist. Du musst nicht dem Schönheitsideal 90-60-90 der heutigen Gesellschaft entsprechen oder nachlaufen. Jeder Mensch ist individuell, jeder Mensch ist auf seine Art und Weise schön. Warum Makeup benutzen, wenn man auch natürlich schön ist? 

Egal ob du kurvig oder schlank bist, lange oder kurze Haare hast, groß oder klein bist – was ist das alles schon wert, wenn die größten Werte deine innere Schönheit und äußere Ausstrahlung sind. Achte auf Dich, stehe über dem was andere sagen und denken. Wir wollen dir anhand eines Fotoshootings deine individuelle Schönheit klarmachen. 

Ein wichtiger Punkt unseres Konzeptes ist es natürliche Fotos von Frauen zu machen. Deswegen steht meine Tür im Studio für jede Frau offen. Bei mir stehen deine Bilder im Mittelpunkt. Ich will zusammen mit dir, dich und deine Ausstrahlung in wunderschönen Bilder festhalten. 

Was ist an meiner Arbeit anders als bei anderen Fotostudios? 

Ich habe meinen ganz persönlichen Blickwinkel, wie ich die Frau und ihre Ausstrahlung ins Bild setzen kann. Wenn ich ein Shooting mache ist es nicht einfach nur ein Shooting, es ist der Moment, in dem ich der Frau das Vertrauen in sich selbst wiedergeben will. 

Wenn sie die Bilder sieht, soll man das Glitzern in den Augen sehen können.

Eines der wichtigsten Punkte in meiner Arbeit ist es auch das Selbstvertrauen einer Frau zu stärken, ohne sie großartig zu verändern, d.h. ohne sie von Kopf bis Fuß hinter einer Maske von Make Up zu verstecken. Das ist dann nicht mehr die Frau, sondern eine Hülle mit einer Maske. 

Ich will meine Kundinnen so authentisch wie möglich fotografieren. 

Selbstverständlich kann auf Kundenwunsch eine Visagistin hinzugezogen werden, die feine Akzente setzen kann, doch mein Motto bleibt "less is more". 

Werden in meinem Studio nur Frauen fotografiert? 
In erster Hinsicht geht es um Frauen, ich bin jedoch nicht abgeneigt auch mal ein Pärchenshooting zu machen. 

Fotografierst du auch Männer? 
Ja, aber nicht im Studio, mit Männern mache ich lieber Outdoorshoots. 

Wie konkret/ wie weit bist du mit dem Projekt ast du schon mit BeWoman begonnen? 

Ich habe mit dem Projekt BeWoman 2014 in Luxembourg begonnen und in 2017 das Projekt weiter aufgebaut bis ich jetzt zu dem Punkt gekommen bin, aus dem Projekt was Größeres machen zu wollen, was ohne Studio nicht möglich ist. 

Gib ausführlich an, wofür das Geld verwendet werden wird: 

Das Geld wird gebraucht, um während der Startperiode die Miete der Lokale zu zahlen. Außerdem muss das Studiomaterial gekauft werden: Blitzanlage, Hintergründe und Möbel, eine Photoshop Lizenz und ein langanhaltender, leistungsstarker Rechner. 

Des Weiteren wird das Geld für Werbematerialien wie z.B. Visitenkarten und Werbung in sozialen Netzwerken verwendet, wo ich mit dann mit einer Werbeagentur zusammensetzen werde, um herauszufinden wie wir das Ganze am besten verkaufen können.

Gib an, wie schnell du das Geld benötigst: 

Da der Herbst vor der Tür steht und das Wetter es immer weniger erlaubt Outdoor Shootings zu machen, wird das Geld bis Mitte Oktober gebraucht. 
Beschreibe, was die Unterstützung für dich bedeutet: 
Für mich bedeutet Unterstützung, jemandem zu helfen seinen Traum, seine Vision zu erfüllen. 

Jeder Mensch läuft durchs Leben mit einem Traum, den er sich ohne Unterstützung nicht erfüllen kann. Bist du nicht auch schon morgens aufgestanden und hast dir gesagt, wie schön es wäre wenn du dir deinen Traum erfüllen könntest? 

Ich habe meine Chance in die Hand genommen, ich habe mein Heimatland Luxemburg hinter mir gelassen und bin nach Düsseldorf gezogen in eine unbekannte Stadt mit der Kraft und dem Willen meinen Traum zu erfüllen. Ich habe einen Menschen gefunden, der an meinen Traum glaubt und mich kostenfrei logiert und mir leichte Verpflegung zur Verfügung stellt, nur weil diese Person an meinen Traum glaubt und daran glaubt, dass ich Erfolg haben werde.

Ich weiß, dass es mehr als nur einen Menschen da draußen gibt der Träume hat, der kreativ ist, der Begeisterung für mein Projekt finden wird und ich hoffe, dass ich über diesen Weg diese Menschen erreichen werde und ich die Unterstützung bekommen werde, die ich brauche.

English Version:

Describe who is going to benefit from your project:
BeWoman - time to be a woman, time to be yourself. We want to show you how beautiful you are. You are not satisfied with your appearance or you feel ugly? 

This is nonsense! You are gorgeous and we will show it to you. We will reveal your beauty whitout urging you to undergo a sophisticated styling to cover yourself with several layers of make up. It will only be you and your natural beauty. 

BeWoman aims at showing to every woman that she is individually beautiful without correponding to the reigning "beauty ideals" in our world. Every human being and every woman is unique an thus individually beautiful. Why sould you use extensive make up when you are naturally beautiful? 

It doesn't matter if you're curvy or skinny, if you have long or short hair, if you're tall or small - your real beauty comes from the inside, from your very own being. 
Respect yourself and stand above silly judgements on your personality or appearance. You are great the way you are. 

Let us help you, through our sthootings, to show the world your real beauty and who you really are. We want to capture your natural beauty, your personality, your emittance. 

This is why we will not bother you with a huge styling or make up sessions and neither will we use computerbased software just to make of you the model that you are fortunately not. 


How does my work differ from other photographic studios?

I have my own, personal perspective .... When I am doing a shooting, it is not only a shooting, it is the moment when I boost the confidence of the woman. 

My main goal is to procure delight and happiness in every woman when she sees her photos after the shooting. 

My work is focused on increasing the self-esteem of each woman without changing her from head to toe or covering her face with make up. 

I want to shoot my clients in the most natural and authentic way as possible, but that doesn't mean that we can't consult a professional make-up artist if this is what the client wants. 

However I believe that less is more. 

Do you only shoot women in your studio?
Primarily my studio is reserved to women, but I'm not against shooting a couple every now and then. 

Do you also shoot men?
Yes of course, but I prefer to do outdoorshootings with men. 

Is your project already in progress?

I've started with BeWoman in 2014 in Luxembourg and I developped it further in the last years. Now in 2017 I took the decision to make a bigger thing out of my project, which isn't possible without my own photographic studio. 

Describe in what you will invest the money: 
The money is going to be invested to pay the rent of the studio in the first time and to buy the material I need as for example furniture, a flasher, a licence for photoshop and an efficient and long-lasting computer. 

Furthermore I am going to invest money in publicity, as advertisment in social networks or business cards. Therefore I am going to consult an ad agency to work out how to sell my project in the best way. 

Indicate how quickly you need the money: 

As autumn is not far away and outdoorshootings won't soon be possible anymore, the money is needed until mid-october. 

Describe what this suppport means for you:

Support means for me to help someone to realize his dreams and his visions. All of us have dreams which we're not able to realize without support of others. 
I have seized the opportunity, I have left my hometown Luxembourg and I moved to Düsseldorf, an unknown town, with the will to realize my dream. I have found a person who believes in me and my dream and therefore lodges me free of charge and feeds me. 
I know that there are more than only one person who has dreams, who is creative and who can find enthusiasm for my project and I hope that I will find the persons who can procure me the support I need.

story:
What is it about?

A month ago #shahenflashmob was launched by young activists sharing Shahen's photo in local areas. In just 2 days the Flesh mob turned into an international action and Shahen's photos appeared in Munich, Paris, Moscow, etc... More and more people were involved in #shahenflashmob. And now we have to take it to the next level.  

What We Need & What You Get

All we need is some funds to be able to print more photos to be able to provide more photos to the public, so getting more audience .
The more funds are raise, the more photos can be printed and, therefore, more great sights all over the world will be  will be captured with Shahen's photo.

story:
It Began in Cocoa Village

 

Fototropix is Dave and CC Christopher from Cocoa, Florida. For 28, years our partnership continues to be a successful journey of education and accomplishment. Starting here on the Space Coast to outside LA in California and the Big City of New York. Finally, we have returned home to strengthen and support our family. 
For the past 14 years, we have been active in supporting the Deaf community. Working as America Sign Language Interpreters, our work has focused on educational interpreting.

Upon returning home to Florida, we have realized that there needs to be more control in the direction of our future path. For that reason, We have formed Fototropix Photography to create a business to work together to provide the needed attention to the family.
With this in mind, CC and I have decided to "jump in with both feet" into the Art community by setting up a fine art photography vendor booth in the Cocoa Village Art Fair this October. 

Our Campaign objective is to raise funds to print the needed images, mount them, Display material like tables and Art walls, and pay for our space in the fair itself. 

For years, we have been observers of the art fairs in Cocoa Village. Now to present our art in Cocoa Village will be a way to

Your support will not only help us purchase prints and display materials. Each one of your donations will go a long way in substantiating us, not just as photographers but as an artist. Be a part of our story when we get to the fair. We are ecstatic to be on the “other “ side of the booth, this time.

 

What is our goal and how we give back


We are seeking $1,000 to purchase items that will make the booth successful. The supplies that need to be acquired are tables and art walls for presenting the photographs properly. However, the lion's share of the expenses will be used on printing and mounting the photos

In exchange for your investment in us, we are showing our appreciation through our art. We know our perks are materially valuable but  a piece of our creative heart as well. We also offer supporters the opportunity to be the patron of a print collection and list their name with that work's title. As "This series of prints for this image sponsored by... ". And as a crowdfunding supporter, you will be provided a discount on future purchases of our work.


Fototropix and Success 

 

Realistically in business, failure can be the outcome. We feel the 1st challenge is not to view this project as having our dream funded. Because if a dream never comes to life.  That's fine "it was only a dream, to begin with.". However, we view this project as a real-life means to direct our journey with our family. 
When it was our determination to move out west. CC and I decided to build a tiny house. With limited building experience. What we didn't know we learned. What we didn't have, we made. The build was successful, driving it from Florida to California. After living in it for 2 years, we sold it to fund our move to NY. Determination and tenacity continue to be the fuel for our success.

 

Other Ways You Can Support the Journey


Each one of you can help with this Campaign. We are sure you have friends you can share our Campaign with. If you have a blog or Youtube channel, mention us there.

We appreciate your time and thank you for your support 

You can follow our progress by clicking the Heart icon above
Share our Campaign on your Facebook page 
Send it out on your Twitter feed
or simply share the link in emails
